title: nginx version disclosure on downloads.gratipay.com

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information:
Hello,

Navigating to http://downloads.gratipay.com/Error goes to a 404 error page disclosing your Nginx version. Server information should be protected since anyone with a bad intent on would try to find exploit for the specified server version.

Thanks,
Footstep
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello,

Navigating to http://downloads.gratipay.com/Error goes to a 404 error page disclosing your Nginx version. Server information should be protected since anyone with a bad intent on would try to find exploit for the specified server version.

Thanks,
Footstep

activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for this second report @footstep :-)

However, it seems that this domain is under MaxCDN's control, because of the Server: NetDNA-cache/2.2 header and the response we have while hitting directly 198.232.127.32. In this case, we won't have control over the Server header, nor the version displayed in the error page—and anyway it's their infrastructure. I think this should be reported to MaxCDN instead.

@whit537: can you confirm this? Thanks!

activities.message:
Confirmed but without any parameter or path, this is the response body,
***
<html><head><meta http-equiv="refresh" content="0; https://www.gittip.com/"></head></html>
***
And https://www.gittip.com redirrects to https://gratipay.com.

What do you say to this?

activities.message:
Confirmed. 

Are you gonna mark this resolved? I want to know your opinion to avoid reputation loss. 

Thanks
activities.markdown_message:
Confirmed.

Are you gonna mark this resolved? I want to know your opinion to avoid reputation loss.

Thanks

activities.message:
I just need to wait for @whit537's response before closing this report (he's in deserved vacations at the moment). If it's effectively an issue on a third-party service (MaxCDN)—that's why I need his confirm, I'll have to close this report as "Informative", resulting in no reputation loss for you (we nearly never close as "N/A"). It'll be closed as "Resolved" only if there is something we can do.

Please understand that we can't mark everything as "Resolved" due to the running [Hack The World](https://hackerone.com/hacktheworld/2016) competition.

activities.message:
I can always wait till after Hacktheworld. I'll appreciate it being closed as resolved though. 
I'm in no rush :).

activities.message:
Regarding HackerOne rules about their "Reputation" system, 
> We believe it is critical to this community that Security teams be afforded a high-signal environment so that they can focus on providing a quality response to hackers who submit the best reports.

Regarding the "N/A" status, resulting in reputation loss,
> Describe why the report was invalid, ineligible, or irrelevant so the hacker can improve.

Regarding the "Informative" status, not affecting reputation,
> The report contained useful information but did not warrant an immediate action or a fix.

Like I said, while this issue seems to be related to a third-party service (which should be closed as "N/A" if we strictly follow the rules and the "Scopes" system), we try to be understanding and categorize it as "Informative". It's not penalizing you and encourage you to try to do your best to only report relevant reports.

I hope it answers your remark :-)

activities.message: I just found [a comment](https://hackerone.com/reports/149710#activity-1068650) concerning exactly the same issue ; sorry for missing it when handling your report. Have a nice day, and thank you for making Gratipay a safer place!
activities.markdown_message: I just found a comment concerning exactly the same issue ; sorry for missing it when handling your report. Have a nice day, and thank you for making Gratipay a safer place!

activities.message:
I'm henceforth always filling the summaries, even in case of full public disclosures. As stated in [our policy](https://hackerone.com/gratipay/):

> Please note that, as an open company, our policy is to fully disclose all resolved and informative issues, in the interest of openness and transparency for our customers.

In our [blog](https://gratipay.news/transparent-security-c864d03d6f60#.jpjzyf5c8),
> Full Disclosure. We decided to go with a policy of full disclosure for all resolved and informative vulnerabilities, including all conversation (no “Team only” comments).

Since no personal information nor complex attack were discussed in this report, I don't see any reason to don't disclose this report. Is there any reason I'm missing for not disclosing it fully?
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
> @whit537: can you confirm this?

Confirmed! The 404 at http://downloads.gratipay.com/Error is outside of our control. That's MaxCDN, not us.
activities.markdown_message:
@whit537: can you confirm this?

Confirmed! The 404 at http://downloads.gratipay.com/Error is outside of our control. That's MaxCDN, not us.

summaries.content: The researcher @footstep found that the web server behind downloads.gratipay.com (nginx) is disclosing its version on error pages. However, this domain is hosted on a third-party infrastructure, MaxCDN—making this impossible to fix and out-of-scope of our program.
summaries.content_html: The researcher @footstep found that the web server behind downloads.gratipay.com (nginx) is disclosing its version on error pages. However, this domain is hosted on a third-party infrastructure, MaxCDN—making this impossible to fix and out-of-scope of our program.
